title: Predicting parking occupancy in a sensor-enabled smart city
segmentation: The doctor will give us about our experience from the participation in Expo.
Added the expanded testbed with IoT infrastructure.
In particular, we participated in the band Center.
Their project, which I guess is the flagship project regarding smart cities in the in EU.
And they will try to give you some.
It's sort of description about the work we've done there, and much more about the experience we got out of this, always from the view of various Boulder price.
Show me a picture is a spinoff of University of Athens.
So we are a team of researchers and postdoc researchers that moved to the industry.

And the our main goal is to develop and commercialize solutions that are based on mainly nicety and technology, but usually combined with other disciplines like civil engineering or whatever is appropriate for each project.
For example, we work with machine vision algorithms for crisis management.
In sports we work in the domain of sunshine formation management on top of a smart infrastructures, and we're quite active in participating in arandi projects, either national or European.
Anne.
The work I will describe about the predicting parking occupancy was made as I already told you, in the context of this month into their project.
And this project there was a fire project, future reader.
Net research experiment.
And it didn't.
It ended at the end of 2013 with great success as assessed by the European Commission.
It deployed in either those things.
Testbed infrastructure in four places in Europe, but the larger new are the largest one was the test.
But blood in the city of Santa there in North of Spain.

So there are they diploid, about 2000 sensors, connected sensors, various tabs for example they try to to monitor their aggression levels at parks and the particles and other parameters in the atmosphere and among them.
There are also.
There are also some.
350 parking sensors that were installed under the surface of streets.
So we talk about on street parking and not for closed parking areas.
The main achievement of the project was to develop to design and develop and validate a middleware that enables experimentation with such infrastructure, either for researchers or for a.
Before the four combination that does the sector.
And eventually the development of end user services.
So we joined the project through a process of an open call for experiments and we developed deployed some applications.
So web and mobile interfaces for the citizens with an emphasis on their parking predictions, short term parking prediction.
Show yeah, these are some photos of the sensors deployed there.

OK, this sensor was deployed in several parts of the city and several streets and we formed the team with ICT researchers and transportation researchers from the National Technical University of Athens.
And where we did several steps in order to be able to to produce something, let's say new.
Initially we did some segmentation on the monitor areas, so according to some studies of the of the transportation researchers we identified 4 main regions in the city and.
Where the essentials of course were installed.

And then we started collecting every day and every minute readings from the sensors in order to be able to build that database that would enable further experimentation with the services we had in mind.
We used part of this data set as a training data set for the prediction models and there we evaluated as usual the prediction accuracy and other things with the rest of the data.
And finally, we visualized the results and the services to in order the citizens to be able to use them and access them.
And something that the user can see and have access to is something like this.
We have web and mobile interfaces where we have as you can see we have, let's say define some city blocks, the cycling's.
Their small icons are the individual parking slots that were a sensor enabled.
And the green one are of course, the the places that are through the park.

At the time we do the readings and if you click in or in any one of these areas you can see the probability to find a parking place in 510 or 15 minutes ahead and an estimation of how many free slots will be there then.
Of course, given the rich data set, we concluded too many other interesting insights that I believe that interested more from.
Transportation perspective or a city planning perspective.
For example, some rules about the the variability of the parking coupons in specific regions or the probability to find a free parking slot in the next 5 minutes.
Given that in the previous five minutes there was.
And based on the readings from the previous minutes from the visuals of previous time and so on, a lot of a lot of data came out of this.
I will not give you many details about this.
There are.
Recommended.
In publications.
Anne.
Now coming to the overall experience we had.

One thing is that OK, that infrastructure allowed us to really easily get access to the data to the available data and so we avoided implementing too much code that was outside the scope of our real goal.
Of course there were.
There were some problems.
One of them was that it was easy to.
It was not very easy to verify the let's say the faults in the servers or whether the data were valid.
Many times will show that some sensors were not so up-to-date, and so on.
Some values will trip.
Moreover, we identified some performance problems in Europe limitation.
OK, it was a big amount of data.
Maybe it's not big data like many people define it, but it was a big amount of data so we very quickly came to let's say to face some performance problems which would sort afterwards.
What is for sure is that.
We could never afford to do all this work and to experiment in with such applications if it were not for such an infrastructure available.
OK, with probably we would not even try to test this idea, which is, I believe it's quite novel.

Given the literature that difficult, directory worldwide would never try to do this if we didn't have the resources for the project and also the infrastructure in order to be able to very, very quickly validate our ideas, OK?
Another reason is that such application heavily depends on research results, so we can never be sure that it has a market potential.
OK.
The overall added value we got out of this as more the price was that we were able to validate some algorithms and some applications with real data and this is very important.
We came up with a new service offering we already had developed a multi modal routing engine that provided instructions, navigation instructions.
Yeah, for combined transportation with public means now who can include this cars too and we can address questions like.
Located the best available parking area in the city center perimeter from which you can easily reach your destination by public transport.
For example, with 1000.
And now we are in contact with some sensor node vendors in order to investigate whether this, let's say prototype can lead to joint venture to be able to commercialize it.
Some final remarks.
That I believe that there are relevant to this forum is that this is not the only idea we have about that in in involves the data OK, big amount of data.
For example, we have at least two more algorithms that we have worked on and which we cannot validate easily because we do not have a good data sources.
One of them is on full diagnosis for this matter.
For structures and specifically ships.
And then the other one is assistant will be limited with proactively routing of public transport commuters.
Basically based on the delays of the buses.
But both of them are almost ready to test by.
We cannot do it because for example in Athens there is not fit fleet management system with the buses.
And even if there was, I didn't know if it was open to companies and so on.
Yeah, so I believe that there is a real need for for such open data, or at least for data that under certain conditions can be used by companies.
An I believe overall that open data can help and smaller prize to rapidly develop and prototype and decide on the potential of a new idea or new venture.
And of course we can do quality checks in our ideas.
OK, we can also stress test the services would develop and do performance check.
And let's say you get the first client reference and marketing material for further exploitation.
Of course, I know that if you use open data or other types of data, you do not necessarily have a client reference, but somehow it can work like this.

Ann and I believe that the message that they would have to share to the data owners, either their their pop in the public domain or the private sector is that there are a lot of ideas out there and you could let the data joined them.
So I would like to thank you for your attention.
These are some cases not interested in our technology and system.
If you have any questions, I will be happy to answer them.
